t: Isaiah 28
Woe*p to the crown of pride, to the drunkards of Ephraim, whose glorious beauty is a fading flower, which are on the head of the fat valleys of them that are overcome with wine!
Behold,*p the Lord hath a mighty and strong one, which as a tempest of hail and a destroying storm, as a flood of mighty waters overflowing, shall cast down to the earth with the hand.
The*p crown of pride, the drunkards of Ephraim, shall be trodden under feet:

And*p the glorious beauty, which is on the head of the fat valley, shall be a fading flower, and as the hasty fruit before the summer; which when he that looketh upon it seeth, while it is yet in his hand he eateth it up.
In*p that day shall the Lord*s of hosts be for a crown of glory, and for a diadem of beauty, unto the residue of his people,
And*p for a spirit of judgment to him that sitteth in judgment, and for strength to them that turn the battle to the gate.

But*p they also have erred through wine, and through strong drink are out of the way; the priest and the prophet have erred through strong drink, they are swallowed up of wine, they are out of the way through strong drink; they err in vision, they stumble in judgment.
For*p all tables are full of vomit and filthiness, so that there is no place clean.
Whom*p shall he teach knowledge? and whom shall he make to understand doctrine? them that are weaned from the milk, and drawn from the breasts.
For*p precept must be upon precept, precept upon precept; line upon line, line upon line; here a little, and there a little:
For*p with stammering lips and another tongue will he speak to this people.
To*p whom he said, This is the rest wherewith ye may cause the weary to rest; and this is the refreshing: yet they would not hear.

But*p the word of the Lord*s was unto them precept upon precept, precept upon precept; line upon line, line upon line; here a little, and there a little; that they might go, and fall backward, and be broken, and snared, and taken.
Wherefore*p hear the word of the Lord,*s ye scornful men, that rule this people which is in Jerusalem.

Because*p ye have said, We have made a covenant with death, and with hell are we at agreement; when the overflowing scourge shall pass through, it shall not come unto us: for we have made lies our refuge, and under falsehood have we hid ourselves:
Therefore*p thus saith the Lord God,*s Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste.
Judgment*p also will I lay to the line, and righteousness to the plummet: and the hail shall sweep away the refuge of lies, and the waters shall overflow the hiding place.
And*p your covenant with death shall be disannulled, and your agreement with hell shall not stand; when the overflowing scourge shall pass through, then ye shall be trodden down by it.
From*p the time that it goeth forth it shall take you: for morning by morning shall it pass over, by day and by night: and it shall be a vexation only to understand the report.
For*p the bed is shorter than that a man can stretch himself on it: and the covering narrower than that he can wrap himself in it.
For*p the Lord*s shall rise up as in mount Perazim, he shall be wroth as in the valley of Gibeon, that he may do his work, his strange work; and bring to pass his act, his strange act.
Now*p therefore be ye not mockers, lest your bands be made strong: for I have heard from the Lord God*s of hosts a consumption, even determined upon the whole earth.
Give*p ye ear, and hear my voice; hearken, and hear my speech.
Doth*p the plowman plow all day to sow? doth he open and break the clods of his ground?
When*p he hath made plain the face thereof, doth he not cast abroad the fitches, and scatter the cummin, and cast in the principal wheat and the appointed barley and the rie in their place?
For*p his God doth instruct him to discretion, and doth teach him.
For*p the fitches are not threshed with a threshing instrument, neither is a cart wheel turned about upon the cummin; but the fitches are beaten out with a staff, and the cummin with a rod.
Bread*p corn is bruised; because he will not ever be threshing it, nor break it with the wheel of his cart, nor bruise it with his horsemen.
This*p also cometh forth from the Lord*s of hosts, which is wonderful in counsel, and excellent in working.
